LIFE754
Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two scientific reports and a presentation.
Educational Aims
To illustrate the value of proteomics and metabolomics towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. To offer demonstrations in the design and synthesis of proteomic and metabolomics experiments, including practical demonstrations within the metabolomics and proteomics facilities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two a scientific reports and a presentation.
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Omics techniques
Overview of proteomics and metabolomics
Introduction to the module, outline course structure and assessment strategy

2. Proteomics techniques and applications
Discussion of experimental design and data acquisition
Description of label-free and isotopic labelling quantification strategies and label-based quantitative proteomics
Advanced applications of proteomics and case studies
Proteomics based assessment of post-translational modifications (PTMs)
Proteomics development
Data analysis of proteomics
Quantification of proteins

3. Metabolomics techniques and applications
An introduction of metabolomics
Importance of metabolomics and different approaches; Linking to other ‘omics and complementarity
Experimental design and data acquisition
Targeted & non-targeted metabolomics
MS specific techniques: Pros and cons of each method
Statistical analysis of metabolomic data
Case studies of metabolomic applications
Metabolites in terms of biological processes or diagnosis
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture

This refers to timetabled lectures from active researchers teaching in their own specialised subject areas.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Pre-Session Introductory Videos to Workshop Contents (E-lecture unscheduled)
Description: Pre-recorded videos (E-lectures) to prepare students for workshops via the University VLE. Engagement with the materials will be recorded in the UoL VLE. In this self-directed learning activity the students will engage with online materials and bite-size videos provided to introduce the tools and approaches applied in the practical workshops. These are provided to link the theory with the practical coding and statistical analysis in the workshops and familiarise students with the tools applied in workshops.

Teaching Method 3 – Workshops
These are to provide practical demonstrations of analytical approaches applied in proteomics and metabolomics and the analysis of data. Students will be taught the relevant coding and statistical training to analyse proteomic and metabolomic data sets.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of data analysis tasks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
Lecture content will be delivered by active researchers teaching their own specialist subject areas – Research Connected Teaching
The combination of lectures and workshops will engage students’ practical research skills through engaging them in enquiry and other forms of disciplinary and interdisciplinary research activities – Research Connected Teaching
The use of workshops to complement the lecture content will allow collaborative and reflective teaching, digital fluency and confidence, in addition to active learning for the students. - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence
Detailed feedback from the first assessment cycle will allow feedforward to engage students in active learning for the second assessment – Active Learning

Teaching Method 4 – Self-Directed Learning
Students will undertake self-directed learning during the module while they are conducting their independent research and working through assessment tasks
Attendance Recorded - N/A
C2021 Hallmarks
Students will use this time to research and perform the authentic assessments, which requires students to undertake tasks which demonstrate meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and understanding - - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments.
Assessment 1 (40% overall mark)
This assessment will take the form of a scientific report (max 2000 words) on the theory and design of a proteomics experiment and the statistical analysis of a dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and assessment of proteomics methodology using examples of the biological questions appropriate to each technique. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the proteomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (coding and statistical analysis).

Assessment 2 (20% overall mark)
In this assessment students will outline their strategy to perform the statistical data analysis of a metabolomics data set and the use of database resources to investigate the observed biological changes. Students will deliver a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy and summarise key findings. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Assessment 3 (40% overall mark)
In this assessment students will produce a written report (max 1000 words) in a format suitable for submission in a research publication to summarise considerations in the design of a metabolomics experiment and describe the statistical data analysis performed on a metabolomics dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and comparison of proteomics and metabolomics approaches to investigate biological systems. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment but will focus on a different topic on the syllabus and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. All assessments are anonymous. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and synthesis from the course materials and associated workshops.
- Authentic Assessment. The scientific report-based questions, will allow students to assimilate, assess and process information in a manner similar to those that will be expected as a citizen or post-graduate level professional.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the analysis and evaluation of research data and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Versions

 VersionDateOriginalDescription 
 3.03 Apr 2025, 11:16
Proteomics Metabolomics and Data Analysis 2025-26
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3 and assess the LOs specific to the metabolomics technique. No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark), assessing the LOs specific to the proteomics technique. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include changes to the assessment and the hours tab updated to include the unscheduled E-learning teaching method included in the overview.

Version Description:
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include these changes.

No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark).

This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Assessment 3 (40% overall mark)
In this assessment students will produce a written report (max 1000 words) in a format suitable for submission in a research publication to summarise considerations in the design of a metabolomics experiment and describe the statistical data analysis performed on a metabolomics dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and comparison of proteomics and metabolomics approaches to investigate biological systems. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment but will focus on a different topic on the syllabus and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. All assessments are anonymous. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and synthesis from the course materials and associated workshops.
- Authentic Assessment. The scientific report-based questions, will allow students to assimilate, assess and process information in a manner similar to those that will be expected as a citizen or post-graduate level professional.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the analysis and evaluation of research data and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Proteomics Metabolomics and Data Analysis 2025-26
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3 and assess the LOs specific to the metabolomics technique. No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark), assessing the LOs specific to the proteomics technique. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include changes to the assessment and the hours tab updated to include the unscheduled E-learning teaching method included in the overview.

Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two scientific reports and a presentation.
Educational Aims
To illustrate the value of proteomics and metabolomics towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. To offer demonstrations in the design and synthesis of proteomic and metabolomics experiments, including practical demonstrations within the metabolomics and proteomics facilities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two a scientific reports and a presentation.
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Omics techniques
Overview of proteomics and metabolomics
Introduction to the module, outline course structure and assessment strategy

2. Proteomics techniques and applications
Discussion of experimental design and data acquisition
Description of label-free and isotopic labelling quantification strategies and label-based quantitative proteomics
Advanced applications of proteomics and case studies
Proteomics based assessment of post-translational modifications (PTMs)
Proteomics development
Data analysis of proteomics
Quantification of proteins

3. Metabolomics techniques and applications
An introduction of metabolomics
Importance of metabolomics and different approaches; Linking to other ‘omics and complementarity
Experimental design and data acquisition
Targeted & non-targeted metabolomics
MS specific techniques: Pros and cons of each method
Statistical analysis of metabolomic data
Case studies of metabolomic applications
Metabolites in terms of biological processes or diagnosis
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture

This refers to timetabled lectures from active researchers teaching in their own specialised subject areas.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Pre-Session Introductory Videos to Workshop Contents (E-lecture unscheduled)
Description: Pre-recorded videos (E-lectures) to prepare students for workshops via the University VLE. Engagement with the materials will be recorded in the UoL VLE. In this self-directed learning activity the students will engage with online materials and bite-size videos provided to introduce the tools and approaches applied in the practical workshops. These are provided to link the theory with the practical coding and statistical analysis in the workshops and familiarise students with the tools applied in workshops.

Teaching Method 3 – Workshops
These are to provide practical demonstrations of analytical approaches applied in proteomics and metabolomics and the analysis of data. Students will be taught the relevant coding and statistical training to analyse proteomic and metabolomic data sets.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of data analysis tasks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
Lecture content will be delivered by active researchers teaching their own specialist subject areas – Research Connected Teaching
The combination of lectures and workshops will engage students’ practical research skills through engaging them in enquiry and other forms of disciplinary and interdisciplinary research activities – Research Connected Teaching
The use of workshops to complement the lecture content will allow collaborative and reflective teaching, digital fluency and confidence, in addition to active learning for the students. - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence
Detailed feedback from the first assessment cycle will allow feedforward to engage students in active learning for the second assessment – Active Learning

Teaching Method 4 – Self-Directed Learning
Students will undertake self-directed learning during the module while they are conducting their independent research and working through assessment tasks
Attendance Recorded - N/A
C2021 Hallmarks
Students will use this time to research and perform the authentic assessments, which requires students to undertake tasks which demonstrate meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and understanding - - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments.
Assessment 1 (40% overall mark)
This assessment will take the form of a scientific report (max 2000 words) on the theory and design of a proteomics experiment and the statistical analysis of a dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and assessment of proteomics methodology using examples of the biological questions appropriate to each technique. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the proteomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (coding and statistical analysis).

Assessment 2 (20% overall mark)
In this assessment students will outline their strategy to perform the statistical data analysis of a metabolomics data set and the use of database resources to investigate the observed biological changes. Students will deliver a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy and summarise key findings. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Assessment 3 (40% overall mark)
In this assessment students will produce a written report (max 1000 words) in a format suitable for submission in a research publication to summarise considerations in the design of a metabolomics experiment and describe the statistical data analysis performed on a metabolomics dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and comparison of proteomics and metabolomics approaches to investigate biological systems. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment but will focus on a different topic on the syllabus and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. All assessments are anonymous. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and synthesis from the course materials and associated workshops.
- Authentic Assessment. The scientific report-based questions, will allow students to assimilate, assess and process information in a manner similar to those that will be expected as a citizen or post-graduate level professional.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the analysis and evaluation of research data and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Modification of this module is complete, please see version description for description of the modifications included.

Version Description:
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include these changes.

No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark).

Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two scientific reports and a presentation.
Educational Aims
To illustrate the value of proteomics and metabolomics towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. To offer demonstrations in the design and synthesis of proteomic and metabolomics experiments, including practical demonstrations within the metabolomics and proteomics facilities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two a scientific reports and a presentation.
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Omics techniques
Overview of proteomics and metabolomics
Introduction to the module, outline course structure and assessment strategy

2. Proteomics techniques and applications
Discussion of experimental design and data acquisition
Description of label-free and isotopic labelling quantification strategies and label-based quantitative proteomics
Advanced applications of proteomics and case studies
Proteomics based assessment of post-translational modifications (PTMs)
Proteomics development
Data analysis of proteomics
Quantification of proteins

3. Metabolomics techniques and applications
An introduction of metabolomics
Importance of metabolomics and different approaches; Linking to other ‘omics and complementarity
Experimental design and data acquisition
Targeted & non-targeted metabolomics
MS specific techniques: Pros and cons of each method
Statistical analysis of metabolomic data
Case studies of metabolomic applications
Metabolites in terms of biological processes or diagnosis
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture

This refers to timetabled lectures from active researchers teaching in their own specialised subject areas.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Pre-Session Introductory Videos to Workshop Contents (E-lecture unscheduled)
Description: Pre-recorded videos (E-lectures) to prepare students for workshops via the University VLE. Engagement with the materials will be recorded in the UoL VLE. In this self-directed learning activity the students will engage with online materials and bite-size videos provided to introduce the tools and approaches applied in the practical workshops. These are provided to link the theory with the practical coding and statistical analysis in the workshops and familiarise students with the tools applied in workshops.

Teaching Method 3 – Workshops
These are to provide practical demonstrations of analytical approaches applied in proteomics and metabolomics and the analysis of data. Students will be taught the relevant coding and statistical training to analyse proteomic and metabolomic data sets.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of data analysis tasks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
Lecture content will be delivered by active researchers teaching their own specialist subject areas – Research Connected Teaching
The combination of lectures and workshops will engage students’ practical research skills through engaging them in enquiry and other forms of disciplinary and interdisciplinary research activities – Research Connected Teaching
The use of workshops to complement the lecture content will allow collaborative and reflective teaching, digital fluency and confidence, in addition to active learning for the students. - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence
Detailed feedback from the first assessment cycle will allow feedforward to engage students in active learning for the second assessment – Active Learning

Teaching Method 4 – Self-Directed Learning
Students will undertake self-directed learning during the module while they are conducting their independent research and working through assessment tasks
Attendance Recorded - N/A
C2021 Hallmarks
Students will use this time to research and perform the authentic assessments, which requires students to undertake tasks which demonstrate meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and understanding - - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments.
Assessment 1 (40% overall mark)
This assessment will take the form of a scientific report (max 2000 words) on the theory and design of a proteomics experiment and the statistical analysis of a dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and assessment of proteomics methodology using examples of the biological questions appropriate to each technique. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the proteomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (coding and statistical analysis).

Assessment 2 (20% overall mark)
In this assessment students will outline their strategy to perform the statistical data analysis of a metabolomics data set and the use of database resources to investigate the observed biological changes. Students will deliver a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy and summarise key findings. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Assessment 3 (40% overall mark)
In this assessment students will produce a written report (max 1000 words) in a format suitable for submission in a research publication to summarise considerations in the design of a metabolomics experiment and describe the statistical data analysis performed on a metabolomics dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and comparison of proteomics and metabolomics approaches to investigate biological systems. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment but will focus on a different topic on the syllabus and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. All assessments are anonymous. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and synthesis from the course materials and associated workshops.
- Authentic Assessment. The scientific report-based questions, will allow students to assimilate, assess and process information in a manner similar to those that will be expected as a citizen or post-graduate level professional.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the analysis and evaluation of research data and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

LIFE754
Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two scientific reports and a presentation.
Educational Aims
To illustrate the value of proteomics and metabolomics towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. To offer demonstrations in the design and synthesis of proteomic and metabolomics experiments, including practical demonstrations within the metabolomics and proteomics facilities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Proteomics and metabolomics represent powerful tools towards unbiased, quantitative and high-throughput analysis of biological systems. Rapid “omic” technological developments in the post‐genomic era have provided insights into protein structures, biosynthesis and interactions, as well as the complex metabolic processes that are of significant importance in biological and medical research. The aims of this course are to provide a comprehensive understanding of proteomic and metabolomic techniques and related data analysis, and to illustrate how they can be applied in fundamental biological research and industrial applications. The module will be taught by lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via two a scientific reports and a presentation.
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Omics techniques
Overview of proteomics and metabolomics
Introduction to the module, outline course structure and assessment strategy

2. Proteomics techniques and applications
Discussion of experimental design and data acquisition
Description of label-free and isotopic labelling quantification strategies and label-based quantitative proteomics
Advanced applications of proteomics and case studies
Proteomics based assessment of post-translational modifications (PTMs)
Proteomics development
Data analysis of proteomics
Quantification of proteins

3. Metabolomics techniques and applications
An introduction of metabolomics
Importance of metabolomics and different approaches; Linking to other ‘omics and complementarity
Experimental design and data acquisition
Targeted & non-targeted metabolomics
MS specific techniques: Pros and cons of each method
Statistical analysis of metabolomic data
Case studies of metabolomic applications
Metabolites in terms of biological processes or diagnosis
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture

This refers to timetabled lectures from active researchers teaching in their own specialised subject areas.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Pre-Session Introductory Videos to Workshop Contents (E-lecture unscheduled)
Description: Pre-recorded videos (E-lectures) to prepare students for workshops via the University VLE. Engagement with the materials will be recorded in the UoL VLE. In this self-directed learning activity the students will engage with online materials and bite-size videos provided to introduce the tools and approaches applied in the practical workshops. These are provided to link the theory with the practical coding and statistical analysis in the workshops and familiarise students with the tools applied in workshops.

Teaching Method 3 – Workshops
These are to provide practical demonstrations of analytical approaches applied in proteomics and metabolomics and the analysis of data. Students will be taught the relevant coding and statistical training to analyse proteomic and metabolomic data sets.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of data analysis tasks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
Lecture content will be delivered by active researchers teaching their own specialist subject areas – Research Connected Teaching
The combination of lectures and workshops will engage students’ practical research skills through engaging them in enquiry and other forms of disciplinary and interdisciplinary research activities – Research Connected Teaching
The use of workshops to complement the lecture content will allow collaborative and reflective teaching, digital fluency and confidence, in addition to active learning for the students. - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence
Detailed feedback from the first assessment cycle will allow feedforward to engage students in active learning for the second assessment – Active Learning

Teaching Method 4 – Self-Directed Learning
Students will undertake self-directed learning during the module while they are conducting their independent research and working through assessment tasks
Attendance Recorded - N/A
C2021 Hallmarks
Students will use this time to research and perform the authentic assessments, which requires students to undertake tasks which demonstrate meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and understanding - - Active Learning / Digital Fluency/ Confidence

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments.
Assessment 1 (40% overall mark)
This assessment will take the form of a scientific report (max 2000 words) on the theory and design of a proteomics experiment and the statistical analysis of a dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and assessment of proteomics methodology using examples of the biological questions appropriate to each technique. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the proteomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (coding and statistical analysis).

Assessment 2 (20% overall mark)
In this assessment students will outline their strategy to perform the statistical data analysis of a metabolomics data set and the use of database resources to investigate the observed biological changes. Students will deliver a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy and summarise key findings. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Assessment 3 (40% overall mark)
In this assessment students will produce a written report (max 1000 words) in a format suitable for submission in a research publication to summarise considerations in the design of a metabolomics experiment and describe the statistical data analysis performed on a metabolomics dataset. Part of this assessment will be the appraisal and comparison of proteomics and metabolomics approaches to investigate biological systems. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives LO1-LO3 specific to the metabolomics technique and supports the development of skills S1 (problem solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (statistical analysis).

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment but will focus on a different topic on the syllabus and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. All assessments are anonymous. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of relevant academic knowledge, skills and synthesis from the course materials and associated workshops.
- Authentic Assessment. The scientific report-based questions, will allow students to assimilate, assess and process information in a manner similar to those that will be expected as a citizen or post-graduate level professional.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the analysis and evaluation of research data and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Versions

 VersionDateOriginalDescription 
 3.03 Apr 2025, 11:16
Proteomics Metabolomics and Data Analysis 2025-26
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3 and assess the LOs specific to the metabolomics technique. No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark), assessing the LOs specific to the proteomics technique. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include changes to the assessment and the hours tab updated to include the unscheduled E-learning teaching method included in the overview.

Version Description:
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include these changes.

No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark).

Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise proteomic and metabolome techniques.
 LO2 Evaluate analytical methods and design proteomics or metabolomics experiments to address a given biological problem.
 LO3 Critically appraise data analysis tools and strategies and interpret the experimental data in the biological context

Versions

 VersionDateOriginalDescription 
 3.03 Apr 2025, 11:16
Proteomics Metabolomics and Data Analysis 2025-26
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3 and assess the LOs specific to the metabolomics technique. No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark), assessing the LOs specific to the proteomics technique. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include changes to the assessment and the hours tab updated to include the unscheduled E-learning teaching method included in the overview.

Modification of this module is complete, please see version description for description of the modifications included.

Version Description:
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include these changes.

No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark).

Modification of this module is complete, please see version description for a summary of the modifications included.

Version Description:
The assessment strategy has been updated to include an in-person presentation (assessment 2, 20% overall mark) and modification to the final assessment (assessment 3, 40% overall mark) reducing the word count from 2000 to 1000 words. The modification of the assessment strategy replacing a coursework report (2000 words, 60% overall mark) with an in-person presentation (and questions from academics) and 1000-word report is to prevent the use of AI but maintain the authentic assessment approach of this practical based module. The requirements of the original assessment are split into assessments 2 and 3 and assess the LOs specific to the metabolomics technique. No changes will be made to the cycle 1 assessment (coursework, 40% overall mark), assessing the LOs specific to the proteomics technique. The overview and assessments tabs on CM have been updated to include changes to the assessment and the hours tab updated to include the unscheduled E-learning teaching method included in the overview.
